questions.question_text_1: Identify the examples for Offshoring from the list below:
question_texts: Identify the examples for Offshoring from the list below:

options.option_text: Shell, an oil company based in Netherlands, setting up a data science team inIndia.
Western Australia’s electricity network agency assigns Tata ConsultancyServices at Pune, to support it with an overhaul of its legacy IT systems, aimed at deliveringcheaper and more reliable power.
Target Corporation, a retail giant based in US, setting up Supply ChainOptimization team at Bengaluru.
Tata Motors assigns the manufacturing of its braking system to TACO group.

props.summary:
### Summary of Core Topics and Concepts

#### Industrial Eras and Their Outcomes
- **Industry 1.0**: Steam Engine
- **Industry 2.0**: Mass Production
- **Industry 3.0**: Digitization
- **Industry 4.0**: CNC (Computer Numerical Control)

#### Transportation in Industry 4.0
- **Hyperloop**: The advanced version of transportation in Industry 4.0.

#### Production and Layouts
- **Production Rate**: Determined by the slowest station in an assembly line.
- **Layouts**:
  - **Product Layout**: Advantages include small in-process inventory.
  - **Process Layout**: Requires general supervision.
  - **Group Layout**: Requires general supervision.
  - **Fixed Position Layout**: Requires general supervision.

#### Facility Location Problem
- **Euclidean Method**: Optimal solution can result in a point and rarely matches the center of gravity.

#### Offshoring Examples
- **Offshoring**: Examples include setting up data science teams or IT support in different countries.

#### Production Calculations
- **Cycle Time**: Calculated based on total production time and number of units produced.
- **Theoretical Minimum Number of Workstations**: Calculated based on the sum of all activity times and cycle time.
- **Balance Delay**: Measure of inefficiency in a production layout.
- **Efficiency**: Measure of how well a production layout utilizes its resources.

### Core Equations

#### Cycle Time (CT)
\[ CT = \frac{\text{Total Production Time}}{\text{Number of Units Produced}} \]

#### Theoretical Minimum Number of Workstations (TM)
\[ TM = \frac{\sum \text{Activity Times}}{CT} \]

#### Balance Delay (BD)
\[ BD = \frac{\text{Total Idle Time}}{\text{Total Time}} \times 100 \]

#### Efficiency (E)
\[ E = \frac{\text{Total Work Time}}{\text{Total Time}} \times 100 \]

### Knowledge Graph 

#### Industrial Eras and Outcomes
```mermaid
graph TD;
    A[Industry 1.0] -->|Outcome| B[Steam Engine]
    C[Industry 2.0] -->|Outcome| D[Mass Production]
    E[Industry 3.0] -->|Outcome| F[Digitization]
    G[Industry 4.0] -->|Outcome| H[CNC]
```

#### Production and Layouts
```mermaid
graph TD;
    I[Production Rate] -->|Determined by| J[Slowest Station]
    K[Layouts] -->|Types| L[Product Layout]
    K -->|Types| M[Process Layout]
    K -->|Types| N[Group Layout]
    K -->|Types| O[Fixed Position Layout]
    L -->|Advantage| P[Small In-Process Inventory]
```

#### Facility Location Problem
```mermaid
graph TD;
    Q[Facility Location Problem] -->|Method| R[Euclidean Method]
    R -->|Optimal Solution| S[Point]
    R -->|Rarely Matches| T[Center of Gravity]
```

#### Offshoring Examples
```mermaid
graph TD;
    U[Offshoring] -->|Example| V[Data Science Team in India]
    U -->|Example| W[IT Support in Pune]
```

#### Production Calculations
```mermaid
graph TD;
    X[Cycle Time] -->|Calculated by| Y[Total Production Time / Number of Units]
    Z[Theoretical Minimum Number of Workstations] -->|Calculated by| AA[Sum of Activity Times / Cycle Time]
    AB[Balance Delay] -->|Calculated by| AC[Total Idle Time / Total Time * 100]
    AD[Efficiency] -->|Calculated by| AE[Total Work Time / Total Time * 100]
```

These summaries and graphs should help you understand the core topics, concepts, and equations essential for the exam.
